misconceptions.name: Implemented average-acceleration program instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial and final velocity and time, rather than reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is to read v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Input prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 double values rather than 5 integers.
No loop to process 5 values.
No conditional check for even numbers using modulus.
Output reports 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or written code for a different physics-related problem and did not adapt it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design a new solution that reads 5 integers, uses a loop to process them, checks each for evenness with n % 2 == 0, and accumulates the sum of only the even numbers.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to code structure
Test-driven thinking (checking program behavior against sample runs)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program—variable names, prompt text, formula, and output message—aligns with an average-acceleration task and not with the required sum-of-evens task.

evidence.note: This code clearly targets an average-acceleration calculation with three double inputs and no loop, modulus, or summing of even integers, which does not match the required task.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration based on three double inputs (v0, v1, t), which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers among them.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this submitted code fulfills the requirements of the Sum of Even Numbers problem, or they submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to specifically read 5 integer inputs, iterate over them, apply a modulo check for evenness, and use an accumulator variable to calculate the total sum of the even numbers.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integers.
Code performs division/subtraction calculation, not summation or conditional checks.
Output is 'The average acceleration is...' which does not match the required output format.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a solution for a different known problem (likely calculating acceleration) instead of the assigned problem. This represents a fundamental misapplication of effort.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure the implementation addresses the core requirements: input quantity (5), data type (int), required operation (summation of even numbers), and necessary control structures (loops and conditionals).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code performs a specific calculation (acceleration) that is completely foreign to the prompt (sum of even numbers).

evidence.snippet: double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t; // I think this is right
evidence.note: Performs acceleration calculation; no conditional check for even numbers or summation logic.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a solution to a completely different problem (calculating acceleration from physics) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 integers). This shows either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment or failure to read the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics acceleration problem (reading v0, v1, and t to calculate acceleration), which is entirely different from the assigned task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check each one to see if it is even (using n % 2 == 0), sum only the even numbers, and print the result. The sample input/output shows: 'Enter 5 integers: 3 8 2 7 4' should output 'Sum of even numbers: 14'
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of evens
Output is physics-related (average acceleration) instead of sum
No loop to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
No accumulator for summing even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either did not carefully read the problem specification, copied code from a different assignment, or is solving the wrong question entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) reading 5 integers in a loop, (2) checking if each is even with n % 2 == 0, (3) summing only even numbers, (4) printing the sum. Start over with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with different input/output specifications than the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). There is no overlap in logic or intent.

evidence.note: The code reads 3 physics variables (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration, which has nothing to do with the assigned task of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
Output is about acceleration, not about sum of even numbers. Completely wrong problem solution.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect problem implementation: Solving a different problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution to calculate average acceleration, reading three `double` values (v0, v1, t), instead of solving the assigned problem of reading five integers and calculating the sum of the even ones.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, based on the variable names and calculation performed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The actual task requires reading five integers, typically using a loop and `nextInt()`, and performing operations based on those integer inputs (summing the evens).
symptoms: Reads three floating-point numbers instead of five integers.
The calculation performed is for acceleration, not summing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted code for the wrong assignment or misunderstood the entire objective of Q1, potentially confusing it with a physics-related exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Delete the existing code and start by implementing a `for` loop to read five integer inputs, storing the cumulative sum of only the even inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code (Q1Acceleration reading v0, v1, t and calculating acceleration) bears absolutely no relation to the required program (Q1 Sum of Even Numbers reading 5 integers).

evidence.note: The entire logic implements calculation of average acceleration, which is unrelated to the problem of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Using floating-point variables when integer type is required
misconceptions.description: The assignment requires handling integers, but the student uses `double` to read inputs, which is inappropriate for handling discrete counts or performing modulo operations characteristic of even number checks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student uses `double` for input values, seemingly believing that all numerical inputs should be treated as floating-point numbers, or confusing the requirement from the unintended acceleration problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem specifically asks for 5 integers. The inputs should be read using `input.nextInt()` and stored in `int` variables.
symptoms: Use of `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`.
Variable declarations use `double`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion regarding data types or following the logic of the unrelated acceleration problem which typically involves non-integer values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure that variables intended to store integer values, especially for inputs where even/odd status is relevant, are declared as `int`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `input.nextDouble()` and assigns values to `double` variables (`v0`, `v1`, `t`).

evidence.note: Inputs are read as doubles using `nextDouble()` while the problem requires integers.

misconceptions.name: Wrong number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: The student reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers, indicating misunderstanding of the problem requirements or confusion about input handling.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should read 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) for an acceleration calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly 5 integers from the user input to be processed for the sum of even numbers task.
symptoms: Code reads only 3 values instead of 5
Code reads doubles instead of integers
Input prompt says 'v0, v1, and t' (physics variables) instead of requesting integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have copied or submitted code for a different assignment (physics acceleration problem), suggesting lack of attention to problem specifications or file management error.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. Change input reading to: for loop from 0 to 5, use input.nextInt() to read integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is unambiguous—it explicitly reads 3 doubles with variable names from a physics context. This is clearly not aligned with reading 5 integers for the given problem.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 double values with physics variable names instead of 5 integers as required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: No loop structure for processing multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The student does not use any loop to process multiple inputs. The code reads inputs sequentially without iteration, making it impossible to handle 5 integers efficiently.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes sequential individual input statements are sufficient to handle the problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use a loop (for or while) to repeatedly read inputs for 5 integers, enabling scalable and clean code pattern.
symptoms: Three separate input.nextDouble() calls instead of a loop
No for loop or while loop present in the code
Input handling is hardcoded for exactly 3 values
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem that doesn't require iteration, or lacks understanding of loop patterns for handling multiple inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop: for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of any loop construct is unambiguous. The code shows only sequential statements.

evidence.note: Three separate sequential input statements with no loop structure for handling multiple inputs.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic for even number filtering
misconceptions.description: The student's code contains no conditional statement to check if numbers are even using the modulo operator (% 2 == 0), which is essential to filter and sum only even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should perform arithmetic calculations without conditional filtering based on number properties.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use a conditional statement 'if (number % 2 == 0)' to check if a number is even, then include it in the sum only if the condition is true.
symptoms: No if statement or conditional logic in the code
No use of the modulo operator (%) for divisibility check
All inputs are processed identically without filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a physics calculation problem that does not require conditional logic, showing either wrong file submission or misunderstanding of the actual task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add an if statement inside your input loop: if (number % 2 == 0) { sum += number; }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code performs only arithmetic division without any conditional branching. The complete absence of if statements is clear evidence.

evidence.note: Code performs arithmetic calculation without any conditional filtering for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator pattern for summing values
misconceptions.description: The student does not implement an accumulator variable to sum values. Instead, the code computes and prints a completely different result (acceleration).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should calculate and output a single computed value (acceleration) rather than accumulate a running sum of filtered values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Initialize a sum variable (int sum = 0) before the loop, and inside the loop, add even numbers to it (sum += number), then print the accumulated result.
symptoms: No accumulator variable (sum) initialized
No += operator used to accumulate values
Output shows acceleration calculation instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem (physics acceleration) that computes a single result instead of accumulating a sum.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Initialize int sum = 0 before the loop, then use sum += number inside the conditional block for even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code prints 'The average acceleration is...' which is completely unrelated to summing even numbers. There is no sum variable or accumulation pattern anywhere.

evidence.note: Output prints acceleration instead of the sum of even numbers, showing the program solves a different problem entirely.
